comments.commentBody:
I went to New York after 911 attack. I could see policemen everywhere, carrying heavy guns. I did not feel fearful seeing them with guns. I also did not think that the U.S. is a “suppressive” and “ruthless” nation. Instead, I felt more secure because I knew I was well protected.

I don’t understand why NYT is trying to depict China as a suppressive country in this article. Have you depicted the U.S. the same way after 911?

Nearly 200 innocent ethnic Han Chinese were killed by ethic Uighur rioters in 2008. So it is necessary to deploy cameras to deter such violent crime and bring a peaceful life to civilians including ethnic Han and ethnic Uighur civilians.

I am not a terrorist, so I felt safe in New York after seeing gunned police. Similarly, if you are not a Uighur thug, you should also feel safe in Urumqi. If Uighur thugs feel fearful, then this effect is exactly what most Chinese including ethnic Uighur Chinese want.

This article shows clearly that China's enormous working class must oust the Stalinist bureaucracy and replace it with a government of soviets (workers' councils). Otherwise, sooner or later, the Chinese people will find themselves being ruled by a government of US-backed sweatshop owners and Predator drones.
Looks like the 5 mao party has discovered the NYT!

To Sarah from NY, you said:

"I fail to see how this is newsworthy. Boring."

I was wondering about that too. But then I realized that it is newsworthy, because it is about China. The American readers now have a great appetite for information about China. There is not a single day that the NYT fails to write something about China. How interesting? Why? Does Americans' keen interest in China have something to do with China or America?

http://www.thrivinginchina.com/

They just follow the examples in London and many cities here in the U.S.
London has the most cameras installed on its streets than anywhere else.
How do Brits feel about a police state watching their every move in London

It is a scant 21 years since the Tiananmen Square massacre. In the USA we had books, plays, and movies to warn us about the excesses of power; such as: It Can't Happen Here, Animal Farm, and 1984. The Chinese kill anyone who deviates. What is more terrifying, I suspect, is what they will use to interpret the data obtained. In a fanciful world the Chinese would use the Tiananmen Square model for a computer program; that when the appropriate criteria were met; the program would send in the tanks to restore ultimate obedience and order.

I think that it is a very good idea to have as many cameras as possible in the public area. If you behave as a good citizen, why do you need to worry about it? I do not see any "dark side" about it. A bad choice by NYT this time.

Looks like NY times is really running out China bashing materials these days.

It is getting harder and harder to hype and incite ethnic tensions in China in Tibet or in Xinjiang, and this poor reporter has to resort to traffic cameras for his ethnic "Restive" mongering.

One wonders if NT Times’ China reporters have quota in making stores of ethnic tensions in China. Just like the Race Card in the US, when nothing is working in China bashing, ethnic hate monger always sells.

My goodness..... the principal of  innocent until proven guilty certainly takes a beating in some of these angry comments. I have not detected the planted Republican talking points in the comments sections for several months but I think we may have a new campaign in full swing.

Great. I'm glad Congress is paying attention to ethics.

But what about the private sector?

What about the 750 billion in taxpayer funded TARP that no bank is loaning out to help create the jobs so desperately required.

What about the bill for the two trillion dollar Iraq War that the taxpayers are left with to pay for over the next several generations. while oil companies pump billions worth of oil out of the region gratis?

Hello. Is a little accountability in the corporate world possible while the real people down on the ground are struggling to get by?

The House and Senate both have ethics issues. So unfortunate that reps whom are minorities are the first to be examined. Wish the dirt could be discovered on ALL pols, Federal, State and sadly local. Our politics cannot be changed until our support of candidates gets beyond sound bites, tv spots, and media bashes of all types.

These three cases are not as similar as this article makes them out to be. John Ensign's is further muddied by the adultery involved, by apparent efforts to buy the silence of the couple involved and by the fact that his party, the GOP proclaims its “family values” credentials so loudly.

And this article fails to mention that Charles Rangel faces a number of charges, the most serious of which appears to be failure to report $75,000 income from rental of a property in the Dominican Republic. In comparison with Ensign and Rangel, the charge against Maxine Waters, that she assisted a number of banks, of which one is one in which her husband is a significant stockholder, would appear to be a mere technical violation of House rules.

P.S. The comment by “Mary I.” about “uneducated voters” who vote for Rangel and Waters is an obvious a code-phrase for BLACK voters. This remark is racist and should be removed.
Try searching hospital websites for employment opportunities.  May the One and Only G-D help you in your trying times...

I do not think people really understand the seriousness of this economy. These jobs are posting positions that are not even available. How do I know? I actually got a call today from someone for a position from four to six months ago, and they were finally authorized to hire for the position.

Anyway, I have been unemployed since May 2009. After going through a bunch of nonsense, I was denied unemployment benefits. I have been living off my savings, my tax refund, and any freelance work that I can find. I have applied for jobs on countless sites, newspapers, in state and out of state, and still no luck. After losing my car and my home, I moved to my hometown because I did not want to take my children through the instability. It is humiliating to be rejected for work because you are “overqualified.” I even had one particular manager tell me she was afraid I would quit once I received my first check.

I can sympathize with the woman in the article. Continue doing all that you can do and soon your perseverance will pay off.

Charley Rangel didn't pay taxes on a villa while he chaired the tax overisght committee in Congress, among other things.  Maxine Waters funneled millions in taxpayer TARP money to benefit friends and family.  Who writes these articles.  If these were republicans, the NYT would have editorials calling for the ousters and prosecutions of these Congress members.

I am really sad that the first conclusion people jumped to was a judgmental "Well, why can't she live with her three sons?!"

Why can't our first thought be "How can we help lift Ms. Jarrin out of her situation? If there is a NYT correspondent that can help give me Ms. Jarrin's personal information, I am really touched and would like to extend some money to at least give her a bite to eat and buy her some more time while she looks for a job...

What you mean is, heightened sensitivity within the Washington press corp to indiscretions by Democrats. When it comes to Republicans like David "Pampers" Vitter and John "Hush Money" Ensign, whose indiscretions have gone virtually un-noted by the Times or anyone else for more than a year, not so much.

Congrats to Congress on becoming more concerned with ethics. Such a shame that focus disappeared during the Bush-Cheney years: we might have prevented 9/11, avoided an unnecessary invasion of Iraq, preserved our civil liberties and asserted enough government control over our financial system to prevent our current "recession."

Frankly, the loss of American life, treasure, liberties, jobs and prestige worry me a little bit more than the possible transgressions of Reps. Waters and Rangel...but maybe that's just me.
I really hope she gets this job she's interviewing for!! Thank you Michael Luo for writing this story and telling us about this woman whose circumstances are actually quite common today.

Partha Banerjee this is great:

I like how "the president ...[is] thrown in the volcano of hate." - because Rangel stole tax-payer money? Where is the connection between Rangel's theft and the president? Where is the "volcano of hate", or do you mean ethics are full of hate?

Are you really saying that because people are being brought to justice, who are criminals based on the public record, and have confirmed their criminality by plea-barganing, are the subject of a "volcano of hate?" Then you state, "Disclaimer: I have no special bias for low-ethics politicians"! Well if you have no bias, then why do you call the prosecution of unethical acts "hate?" If the IRS arrests me for doing just what Mr. Rangel did, would you come to my defense and say I'm a target of a hate crime? Then you say, "We need to understand who's doing what now, and why." I would start with understanding "what" ethics are and "why" there is the law, then move on to politics when those are understood.

I don't mean to be disrespectful, but the "why" I don't understand is why it is so hard for a newspaper like the NYTimes to be truthful, and why its readers support this untruthfulness. Perhaps you can help us all understand why this paper is supported in its blatantly unfair biases?
The NYT has the audacity to call this puff piece news? Less than 100 days...

As an immigrant from Europe, I continue to be astonished at the spectacle of a society so wealthy and technologically advanced, yet so socially backward.
In Western Europe, the notion of cutting a person off from unemployment assistance and effectively throwing him on the street is deemed socially unthinkable. It breaks the fundamental contract between the individual and society.
The Republican party embodies many of the more repugnant aspects of the society in my view. There vision hardly extends beyond protecting the wealth of the affluent and projecting military power to gain control of assets abroad. Astonishing that so many are taken in by this.

There is no reason on Earth why this society cannot help this lady and (soon to be) millions like her - for 99 weeks or however long it takes.

This economy will not return to normal until the U.S. rebuilds it's manufacturing base. Americans have gotten way too used to buying cheap goods from other countries where workers are pay 10-20% of U.S. wages. So has the rest of the world for that matter. The U.S. needs to be the innovator, and the American People need to demand that companies like Apple, Dell (and many mant others) build there devices here in the United States. Companies that are "American" or have substantial operations here should be required to hire Americans to build there products. Will the products the then cost more? Of course, but I have a feeling the iphone would sell just as many. With the trade imbalance that we have and the amount of borrowing we are doing we are just selling our collective soul.

It doesn't have to be that way. When trade agreements are just destroying out way of life we have the right to say we cannot sustain this anymore, "we are out". Other countries have significant barriers to trade, yet we are expected to only take the "high road".

And while I am on the subject of unemployment we cannot forget about the illegals in this country. They came here to make a better life for themselves. They cut our grass, work as domestics and do jobs Americans do not want, or at least did not want. There has been much talk about what to do with them. Good people can disagree on this issue. However, before we can do anything we need to seal the border. If that means we have to build a 50 foot high wall, we should do it. After we stop the illegal flow then we can have a national debate on what to do about them. You can't decided how to fix a boat until you plug the hole.

Wow, the right wing talking points are flying around like bats. Let's clear a few things up:

This isn't an article detailing the ethics charges against Rangel and Waters. Engage your reading comprehension skills, read the headline and you'll get the gist of the story.

#17, I always get a laugh when some right wing loopy comes up with a new reason why the Times is losing subscriptions, always willfully ignoring that ALL newspapers are losing subscribers due to the economy and internet use.

#4, rent controlled apartments aren't reserved for the poor. Anyone can get them. The poor in New York City get Section 8 housing.

#2, what whitewash? The NYT has thoroughly covered and detailed all the charges against both Rangel and Waters. This particular article didn't because it's not what the article was about.

Ah, Republicans. Getting eveything wrong for, like, forever.

To #9 Partha Banerjee, the current Tea Party movement was started by CNBC's Rick Santelli, in protest of government debt and bailouts of financial institutions.  I guess the left is supportive of the government bailouts?  The debt?
